column1: Claremore    is a town and the county seat of Rogers County in Green Country or northeastern Oklahoma
column3: 581 at the 2010 census
column5: 873 at the 2000 census.  Located in the Ozark Mountains foothills
column6: the town is part of the Tulsa Metropolitan Area and home to Rogers State University. It is best known as the birthplace and home of early 20th-century entertainer Will Rogers.

column1: This area was part of the territory of the Osage
column2: but they were forced out under a treaty with the United States. During the Indian Removal period and until statehood
column3: this area was a reserve of the Cherokee Nation
column4: which had been removed from its territory in the Southeast United States. This was within what was known as the Cherokee Cooweescoowee District.

column2: bands of Osage Indians settled in this area of what is now northeastern Oklahoma. Black Dog was the chief of a band that settled at Pasona
column3: where Claremore later developed. He shared power with chiefs Clermont (aka Claremore)
column6: settled with his band in a village known as Pasuga
column8: which was located on an ancient platform earthwork mound in this area.

column1: The Osage village of Pasuga was destroyed by Cherokee in June 1817
column2: during the Battle of Claremore Mound
column3: also known as the Battle of the Strawberry Moon. These Western Cherokee had moved into the region from the southeastern United States and were perpetually competing with the Osage
column4: who looked down on them. At the time of the attack
column5: most of the men were out of the villages to hunt bison on the plains. The Cherokee killed the men in the village
column6: and took more than 100 women and children captive
column7: selling them to eastern Cherokee. Accounts differ as to whether chief Clermont was killed in the raid.

column1: After the Indian Removal Act of 1830 was passed by Congress
column2: this area was designated as part of Indian Territory and the Cherokee Nation were assigned much of this territory. Claremore and the mound ere within a part of the Cooweescoowee District in the northwestern part of the Cherokee Nation.
for whom the county is named
column3: were among the first European-American settlers. Clem Rogers
column4: father of the famous entertainer Will Rogers
column5: moved to the county in 1856. He acquired lands for his Dog Iron Ranch that eventually consisted of more than 60
column6: 000 acres (240 km2). The Clem Rogers home (Will Rogers' birthplace)
column8: and is considered an important historical site. Clem Rogers was a major advocate of Oklahoma statehood; he was the oldest delegate to the state's Constitutional Convention in 1907 at age 69. He and other members of his family were buried at the Will Rogers Memorial.

column1: A post office was established on June 25
column2: 1874. The coming of railways to Indian Territory was the driving factor in early growth. Two early lines intersected in the center of town. The town changed the spelling of its name from Clermont to Claremore on September 19
column3: 1882. A clerk recording the town as having a post office had spelled the name incorrectly
column4: and it stuck. The town was incorporated in the Cherokee Nation on May 2
column7: was founded in 1893 by cowboy Joe Klein and is still published daily. It is the oldest business in Rogers County.

column1: growth was aided by the popularity of sulphur springs among Americans in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. They believed bathing in such springs to have medical benefits.  George Eaton had settled with his family in the Claremore area in 1874 and conducted farming and cattle raising. He later branched into the mercantile business
column3: and oil exploration. While drilling just east of Claremore in 1903
column4: Easton struck an underground pool of water that smelled of sulfur. Local physician Dr. W. G. Williams tested the water and marketed it as a cure. Known as "Radium Water"
column6: but hydrogen sulfide and sulfur compounds that were believed to make it medically useful. Eaton built a bath house and promoted the pool area as Radium Town. Radium Town was centered on 9th Street between Seminole and Dorothy. Bath houses were built by promoters all over this area of Claremore
column7: and for a time attracted travelers and tourists for the waters. Only one was still standing as of 2008. first hospital was established in the early 1900s along what is now known as Will Rogers Boulevard
column8: or Oklahoma State Highway 20. The building is standing but has been abandoned and boarded up.

column1: The Rodgers and Hammerstein musical Oklahoma! is set in Claremore and the surrounding area
column2: in 1906 (the year before Oklahoma became a State).  The Quantum Leap (TV series) episode "8½ Months" is also set near Claremore. The movie Where the Heart Is starring Natalie Portman and Ashley Judd fictionally portrays Rogers County and the area surrounding Claremore.

== Geography ==
Claremore is located at 36°18′55″N 95°36′46″W (36.315181, -95.612784). According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of 12.3 square miles (32 km2), of which, 12.0 square miles (31 km2) of it is land and 0.2 square miles (0.52 km2) of it (1.96%) is water.
The city located in Green Country, a popular nickname for northeast Oklahoma that stems from the region's green vegetation and relatively high number of hills and lakes compared to central and western areas of Oklahoma. Claremore lies near the Verdigris River with undulating terrain producing hills and valleys. The town primary water sources are Claremore and Oologah Lake, both within the drainage basin of the Verdigris River.


=== Climate ===
Claremore experiences a humid subtropical climate with cold winters and hot summers.


== Transportation ==

Claremore is a major intersection of heavily traveled highways. Interstate 44 crosses the town to its southeast. State Highway 66 (historic US-66) was designated along with one of the main east–west roads of the town. State Highway 88 and State Highway 20 intersect within the town 
Two railroads, the St. Louis, Iron Mountain, and Southern Railway (now controlled by Union Pacific) and the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway or Frisco" (now controlled by BNSF)
column3: intersect in Claremore. The traffic problems resulting from the intersection of two major national rail lines have led to discussions among town officials about how best to improve traffic flow.

column1: Claremore is home to the main campus of Rogers State University
column2: which grants a master's degree and bachelor's and associate's degrees. The university serves more than 4
column3: 300 students. It is the only public four-year university in the Tulsa Metropolitan Area.

column1: Claremore is also home to one of four campuses of Northeast Tech
column2: a vocational training school.  The Claremore campus serves over 200 students and offers both full-time and short-term classes.Public school district serving Claremore is the Claremore Independent School District CISD consists of Claremore High School
column3: Will Rogers Junior High
column8: and the Alternative Learning Center.The first school in the Claremore area was opened to students in 1870.  The first major high school was built in 1919; it was the most expensive public school building in the state of Oklahoma at the time. The building was used as a school for almost 80 years
column9: until 1999. The increasing costs of maintenance of the old building forced its closure.

column1: Claremore's economy is diversified. Baker Hughes
column3: has a large presence in the town. Together with several other large companies
column4: it is located in Claremore Industrial Park. This is only a few miles from the Tulsa Port of Catoosa
column5: located on the Verdigris and Arkansas rivers. Coal mining is also an important industry; strip-style mines are operating on both the north and south sides of town.
